summary: Module alias imports (using module-alias package) don't work in workflow interceptors because the bundler doesn't recognize the aliases. User needs to configure webpack resolver aliases in bundleWorkflowCode() options.
userImpact: Users cannot use module alias imports in workflow interceptors without manually updating all imports to relative paths and recursively updating all dependencies.
rootCause: The workflow bundler uses Webpack which doesn't automatically apply module-alias configuration; aliases must be explicitly configured in the webpack config via webpackConfigHook.
proposedFix: Configure webpack resolver aliases in bundleWorkflowCode() options using webpackConfigHook to map aliases, or use TsconfigPathsPlugin to read tsconfig.json paths.
workaround: Convert all module-alias imports to relative paths in interceptor files and their dependencies, or configure webpackConfigHook with aliases.
resolutionDetails: User resolved by implementing webpackConfigHook with TsconfigPathsPlugin to apply tsconfig path aliases to webpack bundler configuration.
keyQuote: module-alias's magic doesn't automatically extend to bundlers. You will therefore need to provide specific configuration to the Workflow Bundler to apply your aliases.
